articles.headline: Suspicions Turn to Cricket’s Dark Side
articles.snippet: The strangling death of the coach of Pakistan’s national cricket team has gained the world’s attention.
articles.abstract: The strangling death of the coach of Pakistan’s national cricket team has gained the world’s attention.
articles.lead_paragraph: KINGSTON, Jamaica, March 23 — Cricket, especially that rambunctious form of the sport practiced in the Caribbean, has always been about far more than the ball, the wickets and the smartly dressed men standing out in the sun.

articles.headline: Public Takes Up Pros and Cons of Edwards Bid
articles.snippet: John Edwards’s decision to continue his bid to be the Democratic nominee for president despite his wife’s illness raises questions of love and ambition.
articles.abstract: John Edwards’s decision to continue his bid to be the Democratic nominee for president despite his wife’s illness raises questions of love and ambition.
articles.lead_paragraph: DENVER, March 23 — Important policy debates about the course of the nation in the next presidential election are still out there and will no doubt return. But for one day, many people all over the country seemed able to pause and reflect on something deeper, to questions of mortality and the bonds of marriage, ambition and devotion, hope and denial.

articles.headline: Tax Loans Are Losing Some Allure
articles.snippet: Refund anticipation loans, the money-making service provided by tax preparers, appear to be falling on hard times.
articles.abstract: Refund anticipation loans, the money-making service provided by tax preparers, appear to be falling on hard times.
articles.lead_paragraph: Refund anticipation loans have been a profitable business for tax preparers like H&R Block and Jackson Hewitt.

articles.headline: Pediatricians Voice Anger Over Costs of Vaccines
articles.snippet: Doctors say the soaring cost of new vaccines makes it difficult for them to buy the shots they give their patients.
articles.abstract: Doctors say the soaring cost of new vaccines makes it difficult for them to buy the shots they give their patients.
articles.lead_paragraph: The nation’s pediatricians, the foot soldiers in the campaign to vaccinate America’s children, are starting to revolt.

articles.headline: Europeans Are Kicking Off a Quiet Revolution in Worldwide Banking
articles.snippet: Even if Barclays and ABN fail to combine, the talks may help start a round of cross-border banking mergers in Europe.
articles.abstract: Even if Barclays and ABN fail to combine, the talks may help start a round of cross-border banking mergers in Europe.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON, March 23 — In the snow-covered mountains of Davos, Switzerland, top executives of Barclays, the British bank, and ABN Amro, a Dutch rival, ran into each other at the World Economic Forum in January.

articles.headline: Fraud Inquiry Looks at Lawyers in Diet-Drug Case
articles.snippet: Lawyers in the fen-phen case defrauded their clients and kept the bulk of the money for themselves, a judge ruled.
articles.abstract: Lawyers in the fen-phen case defrauded their clients and kept the bulk of the money for themselves, a judge ruled.
articles.lead_paragraph: LEXINGTON, Ky., March 22 — W. L. Carter knew there was something fishy going on when he went to his lawyers’ office a few years ago to pick up his settlement check for the heart damage he had sustained from taking the diet drug combination fen-phen.

articles.headline: Discreet Swiss Banks Now Offering Sophisticated Investment Vehicles
articles.snippet: Switzerland’s banks can now be found throughout the world, selling more sophisticated investment vehicles to attract high-net-worth individuals.
articles.abstract: Switzerland’s banks can now be found throughout the world, selling more sophisticated investment vehicles to attract high-net-worth individuals.
articles.lead_paragraph: GENEVA — The new headquarters of Pictet & Cie. is a modern glass-and-steel high rise on this city’s edge, wedged between a Shell gas station and a cut-rate electronics outlet.

articles.headline: South Africa Lowers Voice on Human Rights
articles.snippet: Many analysts are questioning why South Africa has taken some incongruous positions on human rights issues.
articles.abstract: Many analysts are questioning why South Africa has taken some incongruous positions on human rights issues.
articles.lead_paragraph: JOHANNESBURG, March 23  Modern South Africa came about, historians agree, in part because of the United Nations’ unrelenting stance against apartheid. The United Nations affirmed that South African racism was not merely an internal political problem, but a threat to southern Africa. It banned arms shipments to South Africa. It demanded fair treatment of black dissidents.

articles.headline: Foreigners Get Benefit of Tax Cut
articles.snippet: A 2003 tax cut includes a provision that has given some foreign companies a financial advantage over their U.S. competitors.
articles.abstract: A 2003 tax cut includes a provision that has given some foreign companies a financial advantage over their U.S. competitors.

articles.headline: Will Diners Still Swallow This?
articles.snippet: On your plate, a battle between profit and portions.
articles.abstract: On your plate, a battle between profit and portions.
articles.lead_paragraph: CARROLLTON, Tex.

articles.headline: Dogs at the Office: Not Always So Cute
articles.snippet: Tension between the indulgent and the resistant.
articles.abstract: Tension between the indulgent and the resistant.
articles.lead_paragraph: I HAVE gotten a most unusual rush of mail since my last column — photographs of Katie the wheaten terrier, Olive the Jack Russell terrier, Harley the toy poodle, and Nukka and Brody, who appear to be border collies and who seem to be sharing an office cubicle with a python who looks to be in the midst of digesting what I can only hope is not a colleague’s pet.

articles.headline: Slow Down, Brave Multitasker, and Don’t Read This in Traffic
articles.snippet: Think you can juggle the phone, e-mail, instant messages and work? New research shows the limits of multitasking.
articles.abstract: Think you can juggle the phone, e-mail, instant messages and work? New research shows the limits of multitasking.
articles.lead_paragraph: Confident multitaskers of the world, could I have your attention?

articles.headline: Making Managers Pay, Literally
articles.snippet: Judging by this season’s executive pay filings, provisions that would require so-called clawbacks of pay are becoming much more prevalent at major corporations.
articles.abstract: Judging by this season’s executive pay filings, provisions that would require so-called clawbacks of pay are becoming much more prevalent at major corporations.
articles.lead_paragraph: SHAREHOLDERS have been rightly aggrieved in recent years at their boards’ reluctance to recover money paid to executives involved in financial misconduct. While cooking the books to generate hefty pay became common in Scandalot — what regulators say happened at Fannie Mae, Bristol-Myers Squibb and Computer Associates — instances where even some of that money was returned to shareholders have been depressingly rare.

articles.headline: It’s a Brawl. China’s Gamblers Are the Prize.
articles.snippet: Stanley Ho’s casino empire in Macao is under assault from a group of ambitious Las Vegas tycoons.
articles.abstract: Stanley Ho’s casino empire in Macao is under assault from a group of ambitious Las Vegas tycoons.
articles.lead_paragraph: Macao

articles.headline: Security Council Votes to Tighten Iran Sanctions
articles.snippet: Senior American officials hailed the new resolution as a significant rebuke to Iran, and predicted that it would leave Tehran more isolated.
articles.abstract: Senior American officials hailed the new resolution as a significant rebuke to Iran, and predicted that it would leave Tehran more isolated.
articles.lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS, March 24 — The United Nations Security Council unanimously agreed Saturday to impose new, more stringent sanctions to press Iran to suspend uranium enrichment and rejoin negotiations over its nuclear program.

articles.headline: Diamonds Move From Blood to Sweat and Tears
articles.snippet: Although diamond mining in Sierra Leone is no longer the bloody affair of a long civil war, it is still a grim business.
articles.abstract: Although diamond mining in Sierra Leone is no longer the bloody affair of a long civil war, it is still a grim business.
articles.lead_paragraph: KOIDU, Sierra Leone — The tiny stone settled into the calloused grooves of Tambaki Kamanda’s palm, its dull yellow glint almost indiscernible even in the noontime glare.

articles.headline: In the Hospital, Mrs. Edwards Set Campaign’s Fate
articles.snippet: Elizabeth Edwards said her husband’s presidential bid was not only about his needs and desires, but also her own life.
articles.abstract: Elizabeth Edwards said her husband’s presidential bid was not only about his needs and desires, but also her own life.
articles.lead_paragraph: LAS VEGAS, March 24 — As the nurse fumbled to find the vein in her arm last Wednesday and Elizabeth Edwards was bracing for the worst possible news, her decision about her husband’s presidential campaign was sealed.

articles.headline: Hot Spectrum Draws Cash, and Ideals
articles.snippet: A federal auction for a prized swath of spectrum has touched off an intense lobbying effort pitting cellular companies against new players interested in the mobile Internet.
articles.abstract: A federal auction for a prized swath of spectrum has touched off an intense lobbying effort pitting cellular companies against new players interested in the mobile Internet.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO, March 25 — It is referred to as the last beachfront property in the wireless world — a prized swath of spectrum that is about to be sold at federal auction. And it has touched off an intense lobbying effort pitting cellular companies against a variety of new players interested in the potential of a next-generation mobile Internet.

articles.headline: Failing Schools See a Solution in Longer Day
articles.snippet: Spurred by grim test results, districts are moving to longer days, but many teachers and parents are critical.
articles.abstract: Spurred by grim test results, districts are moving to longer days, but many teachers and parents are critical.
articles.lead_paragraph: FALL RIVER, Mass. — States and school districts nationwide are moving to lengthen the day at struggling schools, spurred by grim test results suggesting that more than 10,000 schools are likely to be declared failing under federal law next year.

articles.headline: The Circular Firing Squad in California
articles.snippet: Even with a big gun pointed at the newspaper business, most of the weapons at The Los Angeles Times seemed to be pointed inside.
articles.abstract: Even with a big gun pointed at the newspaper business, most of the weapons at The Los Angeles Times seemed to be pointed inside.
articles.lead_paragraph: Reporting on the contretemps at The Los Angeles Times last week brings to mind a scene in which you come upon a sinking vessel and see people scrambling everywhere. And then you realize they are not looking for buckets, but guns.

articles.headline: New Crop of Books on the Evils of Wall Street Misses Old Standards
articles.snippet: A new crop of books about Wall Street aims to capture, if not update, the rich mix of greed, striving, intrigue and vanity.
articles.abstract: A new crop of books about Wall Street aims to capture, if not update, the rich mix of greed, striving, intrigue and vanity.
articles.lead_paragraph: In his 1958 novel “From the Terrace,” John O’Hara told the story of how Alfred Eaton deployed a suave manner and ruthless ambition to scale Wall Street’s peaks, only to find himself out of a job at the age of 52.

articles.headline: Buyer of Distressed Properties Sees Opportunity in Newspapers
articles.snippet: Samuel Zell, who made billions in real estate, is seeing inefficient markets once again, this time in newspapers.
articles.abstract: Samuel Zell, who made billions in real estate, is seeing inefficient markets once again, this time in newspapers.
articles.lead_paragraph: Samuel Zell’s first foray into publishing came when he was in high school in the 1950s. He would visit the magazine vendors under the El tracks in Chicago and buy up copies of Playboy for 50 cents. Then he would go home to the suburbs and sell the magazines to his pals for three or four times what he paid.
articles.byline: By Katharine Q. Seelye and Terry Pristin

articles.headline: Sunni Baghdad Becomes Land of Silent Ruins
articles.snippet: Far more than in Shiite areas, sectarian hatred has shredded what remained of community life and created a cycle of violence in Sunni neighborhoods of Baghdad.
articles.abstract: Far more than in Shiite areas, sectarian hatred has shredded what remained of community life and created a cycle of violence in Sunni neighborhoods of Baghdad.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD, March 25 — The cityscape of Iraq’s capital tells a stark story of the toll the past four years have taken on Iraq’s once powerful Sunni Arabs.

articles.headline: The Album, a Commodity in Disfavor
articles.snippet: Record labels are coming to grips with the loss of the album as their main product and chief moneymaker.
articles.abstract: Record labels are coming to grips with the loss of the album as their main product and chief moneymaker.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES, March 25 — Now that the three young women in Candy Hill, a glossy rap and R&B trio, have signed a record contract, they are hoping for stardom. On the schedule: shooting a music video and visiting radio stations to talk up their music.

articles.headline: Aged, Frail and Denied Care by Their Insurers
articles.snippet: Many long-term-care policyholders say that years of premiums have resulted in only excuses about why insurers will not pay.
articles.abstract: Many long-term-care policyholders say that years of premiums have resulted in only excuses about why insurers will not pay.
articles.lead_paragraph: CONRAD, Mont. — Mary Rose Derks was a 65-year-old widow in 1990, when she began preparing for the day she could no longer care for herself. Every month, out of her grocery fund, she scrimped together about $100 for an insurance policy that promised to pay eventually for a room in an assisted living home.

articles.headline: U.S. Envoy Says He Had Meetings With Iraq Rebels
articles.snippet: The departing senior envoy in Iraq held talks with men he believed represented major insurgent groups in a drive to bring militant Sunni Arabs into politics.
articles.abstract: The departing senior envoy in Iraq held talks with men he believed represented major insurgent groups in a drive to bring militant Sunni Arabs into politics.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD, March 25 — The senior American envoy in Iraq, Ambassador Zalmay Khalilzad, held talks last year with men he believed represented major insurgent groups in a drive to bring militant Sunni Arabs into politics.
